column1: Pilonidal dimple may appear as: - A pilonidal abscess, in which the hair follicle becomes infected and pus collects in the fat tissue - A pilonidal cyst, in which a cyst or hole forms if there has been an abscess for a long time - A pilonidal sinus, in which a tract grows under the skin or deeper from the hair follicle - A small pit or pore in the skin that contains dark spots or hair

Symptoms may include: - Pus may drain to a small pit in the skin - Tenderness over the area after you are active or sit for a period of time - Warm, tender, swollen area near the tailbone - Fever (rare) There may be no symptoms other than a small dent (pit) in the skin in the crease between the buttocks.
Pilonidal disease that causes no symptoms does not need to be treated.
